generated_text: The structure of hydrate is of great interest to the scientific community because of its importance in the petroleum industry and the potential applications of hydrates in energy and environmental fields. However, the structure of hydrate has been a subject of debate for more than a century. In this work, we report the structure of neon hydrate at high pressure and temperature. Our results provide a new perspective on the structure of hydrate and may lead to a better understanding of the role of hydrates in the petroleum industry and the environment.

Quantum theory is a highly successful and elegant way of describing the physical world. However, it is not a theory in the ordinary sense of the word, in that it is not based on a classical foundation. This has led to a number of attempts to provide such a foundation, and to prove that it leads to the same physics as quantum theory. One of the most promising of these attempts is the program of reconstruction, which aims to show that quantum theory is a special case of a more general theory. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical description of the part of this general theory that is relevant to quantum physics. This description does not presuppose any analytical structure, and so it can be used to study the reconstruction program without making any assumptions about the nature of the underlying state space.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian, and show that the myxozoan body plan is remarkably reduced in terms of both genome size and gene content. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These findings have implications for understanding the evolution of parasitism and the origin of the parasitic lifestyle. (Less)

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The disease is caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), which is able to evade the host immune response by blocking the action of interferons (IFNs), a class of cytokines that are essential for the activation of the innate immune system. In this study, we describe a mechanism of viral antagonism in which SARS-CoV-2 hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to block the nuclear import of IFNs. Our findings provide a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and could lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies to combat the pandemic. The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. Here, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this demand. This study shows that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase almost everywhere in the world, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase in the major maize-exporting countries. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance, which will be essential to maintain yields and food security in the face of climate change.

Herbivores are a major determinant of plant diversity and productivity, but the extent to which they partition resources is largely unknown. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammalian herbivores in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers, and dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. These findings have implications for our understanding of the mechanisms that maintain biodiversity and productivity in African savanna. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is expected to vary widely, with some businesses expecting to remain open for many months. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, many small businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act loans, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of floating plastic debris, which involve a combination of processes, including nano-fragmentation of the plastic, transference to the ocean interior, and processes yet to be discovered. This study provides a better understanding of the fate of floating plastic debris and its impacts on the ocean. It also provides a baseline for future studies on the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. This baseline is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is a unique laboratory for studying the formation of other planetary systems. The solar system is also a unique laboratory for studying the formation of planets in general. The solar system is also a unique laboratory for studying the formation of planets in general.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the presence of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Here we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is a hallmark of MSA pathology. Our results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would have important implications for the treatment of MSA and other synucleinopathies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues of the body. It is the primary regulator of blood flow, inflammation, and hemostasis. The endothelium is a network of cells that is connected to each other and to the surrounding tissue by a network of channels. The network is highly interconnected and has a small-world configuration, which is a property of networks that is associated with high efficiency in both local and global communication. The small-world configuration of the endothelium is an effective design for the control of the cardiovascular system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are needed by many different audiences. We describe the design and implementation of a data API that provides access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking the pandemic and for research and decision-making. We hope that this API will be useful to many different audiences, including public health researchers, epidemiologists, and policy makers.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes, including the control of heart rate, blood pressure, and breathing. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled, and the opening of the activation gate triggers the collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This study provides a structural basis for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. It also provides a rationale for the design of drugs that can modulate the selectivity filter and, therefore, the channel’s gating. This knowledge is of great interest for the development of new drugs and for the treatment of diseases associated with altered potassium channel function.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by many factors, including the host’s diet and lifestyle. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is still being elucidated, and the potential for the microbiome to be manipulated for therapeutic purposes is being explored. In this study, we report the discovery of a large number of natural products that are produced by anaerobic fungi that inhabit the digestive tracts of herbivores. These fungi are being considered as a source of novel therapeutics, and the results of this study could lead to the discovery of new compounds that could be used to treat infections caused by antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in determining social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by the brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight the importance of brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. These results may also have implications for the understanding of the role of the nucleus accumbens in the pathogenesis of anxiety disorders. This article is protected by copyright. The design of mechanical devices with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the limited knowledge of material properties and the complexity of the device structure. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design mechanical devices with arbitrary and extreme responses through the optimal integration of multiple materials. The proposed approach can be extended to design devices with complex and dynamic behaviors. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and the highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of mechanical devices with desired responses.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of the red blood cell. The hemoglobin pattern in the blood is a reflection of the developmental history of the red blood cells. In this study, we show that the expression of hemoglobin is under the control of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway. We also show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key player in this process. IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is down-regulated in the adult bone marrow. We show that IGF2BP1 is a key player in the reprogramming of hemoglobin expression in the erythroid lineage. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This may have implications for the development of hemoglobinopathies and for the use of fetal hemoglobin as a therapeutic agent. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids, in cancer cells. We found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis confers this resistance, and that this resistance is mediated by the transcription of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central regulator of lipid metabolism. We also found that the inhibition of mTORC1 sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis, and that this sensitivity is mediated by the suppression of SREBP1 and the induction of monounsaturated fatty acids. These findings suggest that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for the treatment of cancer. (Read more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs), which are associated with a higher risk of heart failure than other antihypertensive drugs. Our study shows that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our findings indicate that LCCBs may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of cardiovascular diseases.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal land. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but that the policy has not yet been effective in reversing the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. We also show that the creation of early-seral ecosystems has had a negative effect on older-forest–associated bird populations. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge for the scientific community. In this work, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The approach is based on the prediction of the physicochemical properties of the compounds, their binding affinity to the ribosome, and their solubility. We show that the design of new antibiotics based on these properties is a promising strategy to develop new drugs. We also show that the design of new antibiotics can be used to improve the activity of existing drugs. This work is a step toward the development of new antibiotics. It is also a proof of concept for the use of computational approaches in the drug development process.

We introduce a new deep convolutional neural network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures. The proposed architecture is based on a simple idea: to use dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and to densely connect all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply, and can be used in a wide range of problems.

The climate of the tropics is a key driver of the evolution of life on Earth. The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after the MPT. The use of electronic devices, such as computers and tablets, has increased dramatically in the past 50 y. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) cooling is one of the most enigmatic events in the Earth’s history. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of the magnetic grains and microspherules are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Os in bulk sediments from the YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania is likely mixed with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in the spherules is likely terrestrially derived.

CTLA-4 is a well-known negative regulator of T cell responses, but its role in the maintenance of tolerance and in the development of autoimmunity is still debated. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice leads to the development of a variety of autoimmunity, including myocarditis, gastritis, insulitis, sialadenitis, and pneumonitis. This is not fatal, but it is accompanied by a significant increase in the number of Treg cells. However, the development of autoimmunity can be reversed by the loss of CTLA-4 in thymocytes, indicating that CTLA-4 is required for both central and peripheral tolerance. These findings have important implications for the treatment of autoimmune diseases, as well as for the development of vaccines. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We provide the most comprehensive picture to date of the evolution of beetles, including the origins of their major feeding habits, such as leaf mining and wood and stem boring. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was shaped by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with plants, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following the acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. These results have implications for our understanding of the evolution of herbivory and the origin of animal diversity. (Less)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also provide a proof-of-concept for the application of deep learning to the design of other protein molecules. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report the results of a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation, and suggest that the social-learning conditions in our experiment may have been too complex for participants to learn from. Our findings have implications for the design of experiments that investigate the conditions under which larger populations enhance CCE. They also have implications for the design of societies in which individuals learn from one another, and for the design of artificial societies in which individuals learn from one another. Finally, our findings have implications for the design of artificial evolution experiments in which individuals learn from one another.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is the APOE ε4 allele. APOE is a major protein of the brain and is highly expressed in astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain that is involved in the clearance of synapses. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse clearance by astrocytes. We also found that APOE alleles affect the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which may contribute to the increased vulnerability of APOE4 to AD-related neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis may help to explain the increased risk of AD in APOE4 homozygotes.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is a key to understanding the formation of the core and the evolution of the planet. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the bcc phase of iron is more stable than the hcp phase under the inner core conditions. Thus, the bcc phase is more likely to be the first phase to nucleate, instead of the hcp phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and the core–mantle boundary. It also provides a potential explanation for the origin of the core–mantle boundary anisotropy. This work may help us to understand the origin of the Earth.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased craving. These findings suggest that the reduced reactivity to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the human brain is the only known site of evolution of the language faculty. Despite its importance, how language is processed in the brain is not well understood. Here, we show that artificial neural networks trained on large datasets of natural language text can be used to make accurate predictions about ongoing brain activity during natural viewing of corresponding sentences in human subjects. These results provide computational evidence that the structure of the sentence being processed is predictive of ongoing neural activity in the brain. These findings have implications for our understanding of the mechanisms of language processing in the brain and may also have implications for the design of more effective artificial intelligence systems.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been plagued by instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that many problems in science and engineering can be formulated as inverse problems, where the output of the system is known, but the underlying system is unknown. We prove that there exist inverse problems that cannot be solved by any algorithm, even randomized, even when universal approximation theorems guarantee the existence of stable neural networks. These results have implications for the design of algorithms for inverse problems, and they also have implications for the design of neural networks in general.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to learn from past pandemics. This article argues that the failure to learn from the 1987 “marshmallow experiment” is a key reason for this.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two related bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which have been studied for decades. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that M. lepromatosis has lost several enzymes required for amino acid synthesis, and that M. leprae has a defective heme pathway. We also found that M. lepromatosis is closer to the MRCA of the two bacteria, and that they diverged from their MRCA approximately 14 million years ago. Thus, despite their ancient separation, the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of these two leprosy bacteria. (Less)

The study of the evolution of entanglement and entropy is a central topic in the physics of isolated quantum systems. However, the dynamics of these quantities is not trivial to compute, and the available results are restricted to specific models. Here, we show that the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit can be completely understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is a major step toward the understanding of the dynamics of entanglement in general isolated quantum systems.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has caused more than 5 million deaths worldwide. The only available vaccine, developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, is expensive and requires two doses, which may be difficult to achieve in the general population. Here, we describe a vaccine that is easy to produce and requires only a single dose. This vaccine is based on a segment of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein that was recoded with synonymous suboptimal codons, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. This vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, yet grows robustly at the permissive temperature. In addition, the furin cleavage site within the spike protein was deleted from the viral genome for added safety of the vaccine strain. This vaccine is highly protective in a relevant hamster model, and the vaccine strain is easy to produce. These properties support its potential use in mass vaccination programs. This vaccine may be a valuable addition to the COVID-19 vaccine arsenal. (Read more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. However, there is no evidence that rats were present in Europe during this period. Here, we propose that human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, were the main transmission pathway. We show that a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite fits the mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. However, our results also suggest that the spread of plague by rats was not the only factor that led to high mortality. This has important implications for our understanding of the history of plague in Europe.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in the study of animal intelligence. However, the evolution of brain power, which is the number of neurons in the brain, has been neglected. This study shows that the evolution of brain power is as important as the evolution of brain size in understanding the rise of complex cognition. We show that the evolution of brain power is not only associated with the evolution of brain size but also with the evolution of body size. This study also shows that the evolution of brain power is not only associated with the evolution of brain size but also with the evolution of body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. The molecular mechanisms that regulate cell growth and death are complex and poorly understood. Here we report that the mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) regulates the metabolic state of cells, and that this function may be important in the development of cancer.

Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cell cortex, the layer of proteins that surrounds the cell and controls its shape and function. They are also the main targets of the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. ADF/cofilin is the main regulator of actin filament disassembly, and its activity is critical for cell shape and function. However, how it does so, in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments in a mechanical context, and we propose a mechanochemical mechanism that explains this surprising finding. Our results have implications for our understanding of ADF/cofilin function in cells and for the design of new drugs. They also have implications for our understanding of the role of mechanical stress in the regulation of filament disassembly.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and food intake. They also suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. This may help explain why some people are more susceptible to the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on weight gain. The findings may also help explain why some people are more susceptible to the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on mood and behavior. Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, and that the genetic structure is influenced by geography. These results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the origin of the Malagasy population. They also provide a reference for the study of the settlement of other islands in the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This finding has implications for our understanding of the role of social media in our lives, and for the design of social media platforms.

The ribosome is a key component of the protein synthesis machinery and is responsible for translating messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences into proteins. The ribosome is also a dynamic structure that can be modified by chemical reactions. In this study, we show that the presence of a chemical modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in messenger RNA can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that the presence of Ψ in the messenger RNA can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in messenger RNA can alter the rate of protein synthesis and may have implications for the regulation of protein synthesis. This study provides insight into the role of messenger RNA modifications in the regulation of protein synthesis. (Less)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social relationships, and use of time. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of body size is one of the most fundamental questions in biology. Here, we show that the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment and is constrained by the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size. These results provide a mechanistic explanation for the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals and suggest that the evolution of body size may be more constrained in aquatic environments than previously thought.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the temperature at which it replicates is an important determinant of the severity of the cold. We show that the temperature at which rhinovirus replicates is determined, at least in part, by the strength of the antiviral defense response of infected cells.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a leading cause of infections in hospitalized patients and in the community. This opportunistic pathogen is able to cause severe infections by producing a wide range of virulence factors, including toxins, proteases, and exotoxins. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses its type IV pili to sense the mechanical activity of these structures, which is required for the regulation of a large number of genes involved in surface attachment and virulence. Our results suggest that type IV pili are a mechanochemical sensor that can be used by bacteria to measure the mechanical activity of their own structures. This finding could have important implications for the development of new strategies to control bacterial infections.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades, and this trend is expected to continue. However, the consequences of this development for the quality of surface water are not well understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and show that the quality of surface water is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest that the use of pesticides should be reduced, and that the use of newer-generation pesticides should be phased out.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is poorly understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in the lymph nodes of free-living white-tailed deer in Iowa, USA. We also show that the virus spread rapidly among deer during the winter months, when human transmission is at a minimum. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and suggest that a “One Health” approach is needed to obtain a better understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study highlights the need for increased surveillance of animal populations to better assess the risk of SARS-CoV-2 transmission to humans. This information is critical for the development of effective mitigation strategies and for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. (Less)

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy system, but hydropower is still the leading source of renewable energy. This paper studies the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. Although the role of Aβ plaques in the initiation of the disease has been well established, the contribution of neurotoxic soluble and oligomeric Aβ species in the pathogenesis of AD is less clear. Here, we show that soluble and oligomeric Aβ are the major drivers of an early inflammatory response in the brain, which may precede the formation of Aβ plaques. We demonstrate that soluble and oligomeric Aβ are the major drivers of an early inflammatory response in the brain, which may precede the formation of Aβ plaques. Our findings have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies that target the neurotoxic Aβ species, rather than the accumulation of Aβ plaques, in the brain. This may lead to the development of more effective and safer treatments for AD.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still debated. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal assemblage from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in this region at the time. Our results suggest that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and it is not yet clear how many distinct steps are involved. This study shows that the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, proceeds through distinct steps, and that the steps are not all on the same pathway. The results suggest that the folding of a protein is a multistep process, and that the steps are not all on the same pathway.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on RNA transcripts. However, the role of these molecules in RNA decay has been unclear. Here, we show that the predominant Np4 decapping enzyme in bacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels. We also show that the enzyme that is activated by stress, RppH, recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, the mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is a key molecule in the regulation of the immune system during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a metabolic product of arginine, is a promising therapeutic agent to restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. These results provide evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a new therapeutic strategy to improve the clinical outcome of sepsis patients. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. They also provide a baseline for future studies on the impact of human activities on the global biomass of different taxa.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a dynamical system evolves at a constant rate, without being externally driven, and in which the system’s rate of change is proportional to the system’s current state. SOC is observed in a variety of natural and man-made systems, including earthquakes, sandpiles, fire spreading, neural networks, and financial markets. The origin of SOC is still a mystery, but it is believed to be related to the criticality of the underlying system. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be transformed into a metal, with a vanishing bandgap, by applying a small strain. This finding opens up new opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond, which can be used for applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum physics.

The study of plant disease is one of the most important challenges in agriculture. The development of new fungicides is a costly and time-consuming process, and the search for new compounds is therefore a priority. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide, which is highly active against plant pathogens. We also show that this peptide can be used as a spray-on fungicide.

The male–female reproductive axis is a fundamental unit of evolution, and the process of sperm–female interactions is critical to reproductive success. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and show that the female reproductive tract is a major source of proteins that support sperm viability. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female interactions. These findings have implications for understanding the evolution of the male–female reproductive axis and the molecular basis of reproductive isolation. They also have implications for understanding the role of sperm in the evolution of the human reproductive tract.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, helping to control bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force can be used to switch the conformation of VWF, providing a mechanism for the effects of mutations. This mechanism is important for understanding the effects of mutations in VWD, and may be relevant to other diseases in which VWF is involved.

The human microbiome is a vast ecosystem of microorganisms that is intimately connected to our health. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that live in or on us, is poorly understood. This study is the first to systematically probe the human microbiome metagenomic databases to identify viruses. We find that the human virome is much more diverse than the bacteriome, and that it is strongly associated with disease. These results provide a foundation for future studies of the human virome and its impact on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the complexity of the ACI process makes it difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the lack of observational capability to measure the aerosol–cloud interaction processes simultaneously. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to measure aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The results from this technique will provide a significant contribution to the understanding of the ACI process. This technique is expected to be a significant contributor to the investigation of ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature history of the surface is of particular interest because it is inferred to be linked to the origin of life. However, the temperature history of the surface is difficult to determine because of the lack of direct temperature records from the past. Here, we use the thermostability of enzymes to determine the temperature of the ancient surface. Our results suggest that the surface cooled from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean to the present ∼15 °C. This finding is consistent with previous temperature estimates based on isotopic evidence and provides insight into the origin of life on Earth.

Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in cells and are important for normal physiology and pathophysiology. They are also the targets of many drugs. The K+ channel, the BK channel, is important for blood pressure regulation and is a target of many drugs. It is also a drug target for the treatment of heart failure. The BK channel has two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel’s activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery are spatially related and that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent. We propose that the BK channel’s closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This finding may help to understand the BK channel’s normal closing and may provide a basis for the development of new drugs and for the treatment of heart failure. Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with over 200 million cases and 500,000 deaths each year. The parasite uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell, the host cell, and to cause disease. Here, we show that the parasite uses its binding antigens to alter the physical properties of the red blood cell, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding has implications for our understanding of the invasion process and could lead to the development of new strategies for the control of malaria.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be transformed into a metal, with a vanishing bandgap, by applying a small strain. This finding opens up new opportunities for the control of the electronic and optical properties of diamond.

Influenza is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The disease is more severe in the elderly and in individuals with underlying medical conditions. In the United States, the elderly population is expected to increase by 50% by 2050. Thus, there is an urgent need to develop new strategies to prevent and treat influenza. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the impact of dry air on host defense against influenza infection, tissue repair, and disease outcome. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies to prevent and treat influenza in the elderly population. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of the sentence, from the top (the sentence as a whole) to the bottom (individual words), but there is no direct evidence for this. Here, we show that the brain builds a hierarchy of phrases, from the top of the sentence to the bottom, and that this hierarchy is built phrase by phrase, not word by word. This is a fundamental property of the language system, and it is consistent with a left-corner parser.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt pathway, which is one of the most important signaling pathways in vertebrates. Axin is a protein that is involved in the regulation of the Wnt pathway. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin are not only similar in structure but also in function. We show that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently, and this differential regulation is important for the function of the two forms of Axin.

Obesity is a major health problem, and the causes are not fully understood. Here we report the existence of a brain circuit that may contribute to overeating and contribute to obesity. This circuit is located in the brain’s reward center, the lateral hypothalamus, and is controlled by the lateral hypothalamus’ principal inhibitory neurons, which project to the ventral tegmental area and dopamine neurons. We show that this circuit is necessary for the rapid vigorous eating that occurs when the lateral hypothalamus is stimulated. This circuit may be a target for the development of new treatments for obesity.

Nitrogen is a key resource for plant growth and productivity, but its availability is often a limiting factor. Thus, the ability to control the availability of nitrogen in the soil would be a valuable tool for agriculture. Here, we report the development of a system that allows the control of nitrogen fixation in a plant by the production of a bacterial signal. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to develop a new generation of nitrogen-fixing plants that would be more efficient and more sustainable than current biological nitrogen fixation systems. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation by facilitating transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and incentivizing community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are diverse, and the auditory organs of all animals are part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without an ear. Instead, it uses the web to listen to the world around it. We show that the spider’s web acts as an acoustic antenna, and that the spider can use the web to listen to the world. This is a unique example of outsourcing hearing to an external device, and it provides a new way to listen to the world.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also demonstrate that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing anthropogenic particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic with no approved vaccine or treatment. We report the design of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein that is well-suited for inclusion in a vaccine. The variant exhibits high-affinity binding to the human ACE2 receptor, high-yield manufacturability, and enhanced immunogenicity compared to the Wuhan-Hu-1 sequence used in current vaccines. This engineered sequence may be used in a vaccine to protect against the current pandemic and future variants.

Neuroblastoma is the most common tumor of the neural crest, a group of cells that gives rise to many tissues and organs. The majority of neuroblastomas are driven by mutations in the ALK gene, which encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK-like receptors are activated by ALKAL proteins, which are secreted by neural crest cells. Our results provide evidence that ALKALs are ligands for zebrafish ALK-like receptors and that these receptors are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroblastoma.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the emergence of Yersinia pestis from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is one of the most dramatic events in the history of microbiology. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a unique opportunity to explore the evolution of plague during this critical period. Our results suggest that plague was not a widespread disease in the Neolithic, and that the emergence of plague as we know it today occurred over a period of several centuries. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague than previously thought. These data provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its relationship to its vector, the flea. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. These findings have implications for understanding the political climate in the United States and beyond. (PsycINFO Database Record

The agricultural use of grasslands has been a major driver of the global C cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to cropland has led to the release of 1.2 Pg of C to the atmosphere since 1900. In this study, we show that the use of perennial pastures, which are managed to maintain their perennial vegetation, can sequester 1.8 to 2.9 Pg of C in the soil over 29 y. This is equivalent to the total amount of C sequestered in the soil of the United States from 1900 to 2017. This study highlights the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester C and provides a framework for the design of climate-smart agricultural systems. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of novel viruses from animals to humans. We present a systematic approach to identify and prioritize the highest-risk viruses, which can be used to inform research and public health interventions. We also provide a platform for the public to contribute to the ongoing refinement of the risk assessment. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that this resource will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts animals, but the mechanisms underlying the production of the color are poorly understood. We show that the color of the red nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also show that the color of the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae is also derived from nesocodin. These findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait that is likely to be favored by natural selection. This work provides insights into the evolution of a key trait in the plant–animal interaction. It also provides a new source of colorant for the food industry. (Less)

The history of Europe is marked by a series of major demographic changes, including the expansion of farming populations and the migration of peoples from outside the continent. However, the genetic history of the intervening periods is largely unknown. Here we present the genome of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived at the end of the Roman Empire and show that they had a very high genetic diversity, including signals of ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These findings provide insights into the history of Europe and the processes that shaped the modern European genetic landscape. They also highlight the potential of ancient DNA to provide new insights into the history of Europe.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for cross-species transmission. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. These findings provide insights into the evolution of MERS-CoV and the risk of cross-species transmission of bat coronaviruses. They also provide a basis

We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a larger national outbreak. Our results highlight the need for ongoing pathogen surveillance to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and to deploy rapid public health response. This approach can be used in resource-scarce settings to better understand the pathogen landscape and to inform public health response. This study is a proof of concept for a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform that can be used to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings. This approach can be used to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and to deploy rapid public health response. This study is a proof of concept for a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform that can be used to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings. This approach can be used to better understand the breadth of endemic

The human genome is replicated in a series of short DNA fragments, known as Okazaki fragments, which are assembled by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) and the sliding clamp, proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is critical for the fidelity of replication and the synthesis of Okazaki fragments. We developed unique kinetic assays to measure the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme is more stable than its yeast counterpart and that it maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This work provides a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanisms that control the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its role in the replication of the human genome. This knowledge will be critical for the development of therapeutic agents that target the human replisome.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science, and the RNA world is one of the most popular hypotheses for the origin of proteins. In the RNA world, the genetic information was stored in RNA molecules, and the replication of this information was accomplished by ribozymes. In this paper, we describe the first laboratory system that can replicate RNA by RNA-based ribozymes. This system can amplify RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over a period of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

COVID-19 is a severe disease with high mortality. The treatment is still in the stage of clinical trial. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is approved for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, can improve the clinical outcome of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to control copper availability is therefore an important aspect of their biology. Here we report the discovery of a copper-binding natural product from Aspergillus fumigatus, the cause of invasive mold infections in humans. This discovery has implications for our understanding of the role of fungi in the environment and human health, and for the development of new antifungal agents.

The formation of silica polymorphs in a sedimentary environment is rare on Earth and on other planets. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is a significant finding. The tridymite is cogenetic with the other crystalline minerals, and the amorphous silica is a product of multiple aqueous solutions. The diagenesis of the amorphous silica is not well understood, but the presence of some of the products of diagenesis in the same rock suggests that the diagenesis was not a simple process.

Frost is one of the most common abiotic stressors that affect plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of frost events are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is strongly correlated with the geographic distribution of tree species’ frost resistance. Our findings reveal region-specific changes in the spring-frost risk that can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. Our results also provide a framework for studying the evolution of frost resistance in plants and animals.

The Th17 cell lineage is a major source of pathogenic inflammation in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to these cells are not well understood. Here we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of the transcription factor T-bet, which is required for the development of both IL-17A+ and IL-17F+ cells. We also show that the development of Th1 cells requires the expression of the transcription factor interferon regulatory factor 4. These results suggest that the Th17 cell lineage is a source of both IL-17A+ and IL-17F+ cells, and that the balance between these two subsets is critical for the development of colitis. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no known cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and also by genetic risk factors, such as a superoxide dismutase mutation. In addition, the disease is associated with toxic protein aggregates, including a hexanucleotide expansion in the C9orf72 gene. We now report a method to rapidly and easily produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and to screen for therapeutics. This method will enable rapid and easy generation of large numbers of disease-relevant cells for ALS disease modeling and drug screening. This will greatly facilitate the development of new therapies for ALS. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of the microbiome in the transmission of infectious agents to vectors and hosts is a topic of increasing interest. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the microbiota of the vector, the blacklegged tick, to more efficiently colonize the vector. We demonstrate that the pathogen induces the vector to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the tick gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix, which is a critical obstacle for the pathogen. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiome of their vectors. This knowledge will be useful for the development of novel strategies to control vector-borne diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Birds are one of the most successful groups of animals on Earth, and the study of their evolution is one of the most important areas of research in biology. The study of the origin of the short-tailed bird group is particularly important because it is a key step in understanding the evolution of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a new species of early pygostylian, a group of birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone called a “pygostyle,” and we provide new insights into the evolution of the short-tailed bird group.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for the animal’s survival, as it allows it to adapt to its environment. In this study, we show that the ability to change color has evolved multiple times during the evolution of vertebrates. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most diverse group of protease inhibitors.

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, including breast cancer, and is associated with the emergence of cancer stem cells (CSCs), which are responsible for tumor initiation and relapse. We show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a key factor in the maintenance of CSCs. Our results suggest that ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first pocket Bible was produced in the 13th century. The source of the parchment used to make these Bibles has been a long-standing mystery. Here, we report the results of a study of 265 parchment samples, including 72 pocket Bibles, that show that the source of the parchment was not the use of fetal animals, as has been suggested, but rather the use of several species of animal, including sheep, goat, and rabbit. This suggests that the production process used to make the parchment was more important than the species of animal used.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is a matter of intense debate, but the evidence points to a global environmental perturbation. This study provides a precise age model for the extinction and recovery, allowing a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. The results also provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The study demonstrates the value of the Global Stratotype Section and Point program in providing a precise and accurate framework for the study of the end-Permian extinction and its aftermath. This work will be of interest to all researchers working on the end-Permian mass extinction and its aftermath.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the overproduction of proinflammatory cytokines and the activation of the nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) pathway. However, the underlying molecular mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we report that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a key regulator of the NF-κB pathway in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs). We found that RORα is essential for the maintenance of intestinal homeostasis by attenuating the activation of the NF-κB pathway. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of IBD. This study also provides a new perspective for the study of the role of RORα in the regulation of the NF-κB pathway and the development of IBD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for vaccine development. We have determined the structure of the spike protein at 2.8 Å resolution and show that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike. This may facilitate binding to the receptor and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for membrane fusion. These results provide insights into the mechanism of the D614G mutation and may help to explain the increased transmissibility of the mutant virus. This article is protected by copyright.
