We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry and are fundamental to understanding the properties of matter. The chemical properties of atoms are also the basis of the periodic table, which is the most successful model in the history of science. Here, we show that the chemical properties of atoms can be modified under pressure, and we show that these modifications can be used to predict and explain the behavior of matter under pressure.

We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the main driver of changes in global fire activity over the past 100 y. This has led to a reduction in fire emissions, which has offset some of the warming caused by fossil fuel emissions. However, the effect is small and depends on the strength of the climate–fire feedback. We also show that climate change is likely to increase fire activity in many regions, but that this is offset by reductions in fire activity caused by human demography. This suggests that climate change may be less likely to cause fires in the future, but that the fires that do occur will be more intense.

The mutualism between animals and their symbiotic microbes is one of the most successful and widespread forms of life on Earth. However, the mechanisms that regulate the stability of these associations are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, synthesized by the host animal, is sufficient to maintain the stability of the symbiotic relationship between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan-based regulation of symbiosis stability may be a common feature of animal-microbe associations.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. This method is based on advances in theoretical machine learning, which we integrate with word embedding. Our method is flexible and broadly applicable, and it can be used to model topics in a wide variety of domains. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We hope that it will be useful to researchers in many fields.

The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is one of the most devastating events in human history. The disease was caused by Yersinia pestis, a bacterium that is transmitted by fleas. The origin of Y. pestis is still debated, but the most widely accepted hypothesis is that the bacterium was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. We show that the climate conditions in Asia were favorable for the survival of Y. pestis, and that the bacterium was reintroduced into Europe on multiple occasions. Our results provide evidence for a climate-driven reintroduction of Y. pestis into European harbors, which may have contributed to the spread of the disease. (Less)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important in the functioning of marine ecosystems. However, they are also a major source of food for a number of economically important species, including sea stars, which are used as a biological control agent for invasive species. We report the discovery of a novel densovirus that is the likely cause of a disease that has caused the mass mortality of sea stars on the Pacific coast of North America. This is the first report of a densovirus associated with a disease of sea stars.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is one of the most common forms of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study also provides a proof-of-principle for the use of antibody-based therapies in the treatment of other diseases

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island and to investigate the origin of the Malagasy people. We find that the Malagasy people are a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is recent, with a rapid colonization of the island during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the colonization was not homogeneous, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar from Africa and Asia was not a single event. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a better understanding of the settlement history of Madagascar and of the origin of the Malagasy people. It also provides a reference for the study of the origin of the other island populations, such as the Comoros, Mauritius, and Seychelles. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases the activity of glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, a key enzyme in the metabolism of glycerol. We found that the protein also interferes with the ability of a small RNA to repress two other genes. The protein and RNA compete for the same translation site, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This study provides insight into the regulation of carbon metabolism in bacteria. It also demonstrates that the translation and base-pairing functions of small RNAs compete for the same translation site. This is an example of a mechanism that may be used to regulate the expression of multiple genes. This mechanism may be important in the regulation of other biological processes and stress responses.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may also provide a proof-of-concept for the application of deep learning to the design of other protein molecules. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status, but their assessments are subjective and difficult to aggregate. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is based on the subjective assessments of many crop experts, can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is more amenable to quantitative analysis. We show that the survey exhibits long-term stability, and that the underlying models that describe the reported crop status are statistically robust and maintain similar characteristics across different crops. We discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data, and demonstrate how the survey can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the survey can be used to provide a more complete picture of crop conditions, and can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by a central executive that maintains information in working memory over short periods of time. Here we propose a different view of memory in the brain. Instead of relying on sustained, elevated neural activity, we show that information can be stored in the dynamics of the neuronal membrane potential. This mechanism is based on the idea that information is encoded in the adaptive changes in the excitability of the neuron, rather than in the membrane potential itself. This neuronal memory is sensitive to context and serial order, and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, limiting our ability to understand the response of soil respiration to climate change. Here, we present the results of a global synthesis of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements from 27 temperature manipulation studies. Our analysis reveals that soil respiration does not increase in response to experimental warming in all biomes, and that the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration decreases with increasing temperature. These results provide a unique cross-biome perspective on the response of soil respiration to climate change, and highlight the importance of cold regions in the global carbon cycle. Our results also highlight the need for further research to understand the response of soil respiration to climate change. This information is critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key aspect of the origin and evolution of life on land. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the history of life, but the molecular signature of this transition is still debated. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the worst in the region in the last century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of such a drought by a factor of five to six. This finding is important for the public and policy makers, as it highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also provide a valuable example of how climate models can be used to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to extreme events. This approach can be used to assess the risk of similar events in other regions in the future.

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the “Trinity test,” in 1945, was a major event in the history of science. It led to the discovery of a new class of materials, the search for their synthesis conditions, and the development of new experimental techniques. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown quasicrystal in the red trinitite, the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal.

Photosynthesis is the basis of life on Earth. The oxygenic photosynthetic organisms are the plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria. The oxygenic photosynthetic organisms use a common set of pigments, the (bacterio)chlorophylls, which are derived from a common precursor, the isocyclic tetrapyrrole, chlorophyll c. The formation of the fifth ring of the chlorophyll pigments has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This paper describes the evolution of the enzymes that are involved in the formation of the fifth ring, and the role of these enzymes in the biosynthesis of the (bacterio)chlorophylls. The results provide a framework for understanding the evolution of the enzymes involved in the formation of the fifth ring of the (bacterio)chlorophylls. (Read more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in multiple sclerosis (MS), and neuroinflammation is associated with the development of disability. However, the molecular mechanisms underlying neuroinflammation are not fully understood. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) signaling, which is known to be regulated by neuroinflammation. In this study, we found that apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1), a MAP3K, is a key regulator of neuroinflammation in multiple sclerosis. We also found that ASK1 is expressed in different glial cell types, and ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages, but not in astrocytes, ameliorated neuroinflammation in a mouse model of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation in multiple sclerosis. This study also provides a rationale for the use of a phase-specific approach to target neuroinflammation. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for multiple sclerosis. The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s instrumental record. We show that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased substantially in recent decades, and that this trend is very likely due to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial inheritance pattern. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core symptoms of autism. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggests that the forgetting process is a common target for autism-risk genes. This study also provides a framework for the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core symptoms of autism. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) (SO(2)) channel is a key regulator of cellular functions, including gene expression, cell growth and differentiation, and Ca2+ homeostasis. Mutations in the pore-forming protein of the SO(2) channel, ORAI1, result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of the Ca2+ sensor STIM1, which are associated with a Stormorken syndrome of hematological abnormalities, bleeding diathesis, and miosis. We show that these mutations result in constitutive activation of the SO(2) channel, and that the mutations are associated with a gain-of-function of the SO(2) channel. These data expand our understanding of the molecular basis of dysregulated SO(2) channel signaling, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. Neurodegenerative diseases are among the most devastating diseases of the 21st century. The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a common feature of many of these diseases, and the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous, and that the spreading of aggregates can be prevented by inhibiting endocytosis. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Bats are increasingly recognized as important reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses, and the identification of the immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats is of great importance for the development of therapeutic strategies to prevent and treat viral infections. Here, we report the isolation of a novel immunosuppressant protein (MTX) from the bat, Myotis pilosus, which is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland. MTX potently inhibited the antiviral responses of the host and facilitated viral infection. MTX had no effect on the aminopeptidase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) and therefore did not impair the antiinflammatory function of LTA4H. This study provides deeper insight into the immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of viral infections in bats and humans. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon pool is a key metabolic pathway that is dysregulated in cancer. Here we report the discovery of a small molecule that inhibits both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2 (SHMT1/2) in a dual-inhibitory manner. We show that this dual inhibition blocks the growth of colon cancer xenografts in mice. We also show that the one-carbon donor, formate, can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We further show that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import in DLBCL cell lines, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These results provide a rationale for the use of SHMT inhibitors in the treatment of DLBCL. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease that affects the nervous system and is characterized by the formation of intracellular inclusions containing a variety of proteins. These inclusions are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease, and the proteins that form the inclusions are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these proteins. We show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, but rather are a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. This finding may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for ALS. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The device can be fabricated from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, but the evolution of the human parvovirus B19 (B19V) has been difficult to study. Here we present the genomes of five ancient B19V viruses, which are phylogenetically basal to the most common B19V genotype. We also provide evidence that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. These results provide insights into the evolution of B19V and the evolution of viruses in general. They also provide evidence that ancient viral sequences can be used to study the evolution of viruses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of global change. In this study, we show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the rate predicted by climate models. This finding is important because it provides a direct measurement of the rate of climate change, which is a key input to climate models.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; importantly, tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of the enzyme-catalyzed reaction intermediate in a key reaction of the tryptophan synthase active site. This work provides a chemically detailed, three-dimensional view of the reaction, including the location of the leaving group, the hydrogen bond donor, and the hydrogen bond acceptor. This work also provides a detailed picture of the fate of the leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional view of the reaction intermediate and the active site, and to provide insight into the reaction pathway. Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the available options are limited to supportive care. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS, and may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses. This study also highlights the importance of continued research on the development of antiviral treatments for emerging and reemerging coronaviruses. This article is protected by copyright. The mutualism between animals and their symbiotic microbes is one of the most successful and widespread forms of life on Earth. However, the mechanisms that regulate the stability of these associations are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, synthesized by the host animal, is sufficient to maintain the stability of the symbiont population in a specific organ of the host. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is thus able to maintain a high population level in the organ. This glycan is provided by the host only at night, when the organ is colonized by immune cells that are the main source of the glycan. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis stability, which may be relevant to other animal–microbe associations. It also suggests that the provision of nutrients may be a general mechanism for regulating the activities of microbial communities in the epithelium of animals.

This study shows that it is possible to reduce suspension rates in middle schools by changing the mindset of teachers. This is a scalable intervention that can be implemented in schools across the country.

DNA alkylation is one of the most common DNA lesions, which can lead to a variety of diseases. However, the molecular mechanism of how DNA alkylation affects transcription is still unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the effects of DNA alkylation on transcription. We found that the presence of DNA alkylation can lead to transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop), which is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings will help us to understand the molecular mechanism of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis and provide a foundation for the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of DNA alkylation-induced diseases.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To cause infection, virions must bind to cell receptors and fuse with the cell membrane. We found that the spike (S) glycoproteins, which mediate binding and fusion, must be cleaved sequentially to allow the second, fusion-activating cleavage. Without the first cleavage, the S proteins resisted conformational changes that are induced by cell receptors, and therefore could not fuse with the cell membrane. These findings suggest that the first cleavage is a critical step in the infection process, and therefore may be a target for antiviral therapy.

The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the population have a major impact on this, and it is therefore important to understand how to influence people’s diets. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can have a significant impact on sales. This suggests that it may be possible to nudge people toward more plant-based diets by changing the physical environment in which they make their choices. This has important implications for the design of sustainable food systems.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to engage the extracellular space. We report a systems-level view of how oncogenes remodel the surfaceome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on the 2016 and 2020 elections. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and the share of the popular vote won by each party. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout or vote share. Vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. Our findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global population. The virus has spread rapidly, and the molecular basis for its severity and rapid spread is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein, which is rapidly evolving and has been proposed to interfere with the host immune response. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. These results provide insights into the molecular basis of the rapid spread of the virus and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. This work also provides a foundation for the continued monitoring of the rapid evolution of the protein. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major risk factor for cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats, and that this effect is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) in cortical astrocytes to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε, leading to up-regulation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) expression and edema. These findings provide a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. The problem of selective inference is one of the most important challenges in statistics today. It addresses the fact that we have “cherry picked” data and methods, and thus must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. This paper describes some recent developments in selective inference and illustrates their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to help the reader understand the nature of the problem and to provide a sense of the power of modern statistical methods.

The development of vascular ECs is a critical step in the formation of new blood vessels. However, the development of ECs is difficult to achieve in vitro and in vivo. Here, we report the generation of endothelial cells (ECs) from human fibroblasts using a single transcription factor, ets variant 2 (ETV2). We show that ETV2 can directly induce the development of ECs from human fibroblasts in vitro and in vivo. This study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the formation of new blood vessels. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. Furthermore, the use of ETV2 may be a useful tool for the development of new therapies for vascular disorders. This study may also provide a new strategy for the development of new therapies for vascular disorders. The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of the oncogenic receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) ALK and LTK has opened up a new field of research. Here, we show that these ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized type of skin cells that are responsible for the coloration of the fish. We also show that the expression of these ligands is restricted to the iridophores and that they are essential for their differentiation. These findings establish a physiological link between the ligands and the RTKs and demonstrate that the ligands are required for the activation of LTK and not for the activation of ALK. This work provides a better understanding of the function of these ligands and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of ALK-driven cancers.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem, and the molecular mechanisms underlying its development are still poorly understood. Herein, we report a role of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and insulin resistance. We also provide evidence that STING is required for β-cell function and that its function is lost in the absence of β-cell–specific STING. These findings provide a better understanding of the role of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and insulin resistance and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of the virus is composed of eight segments, which are packaged into virions. The packaging mechanism is still unknown, but it is suspected that the virus uses a selective mechanism to package one copy of each segment into each virion. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments, which is required for optimal viral replication. We also showed that this interaction favors the copackaging of the interacting segments. Our results provide insights into the packaging mechanism of the influenza A virus. They also suggest that the interaction we identified is a key step in the selective packaging of the viral genome. This interaction might be important for the genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Finally, our results indicate that the lack of conservation of this interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This article is protected by copyright. Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular endothelial cells. The present study demonstrates that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by local hemodynamic environment is a key event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the prevention of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a new perspective for the development of therapeutic strategies for the prevention of atherosclerosis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the natural landscape for millennia. However, in the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Climate change has likely contributed to some of the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities over the course of 10 y. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to chemical pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we report the identification of a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel as a receptor of plant-derived natural repellents, which mediates avoidance behavior. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of arthropod–plant adaptation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the time between cell infection and viral production is likely short, the rate of viral production is rapid, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also show that the treatment of ZIKV infection with a drug that blocks viral replication can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load. However, the timing of treatment is critical, and treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. These results can be used to inform the design of clinical trials for the treatment of ZIKV infection. (Less)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are threatened by a variety of environmental stressors, including global warming, ocean acidification, and pollution. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is also triggered by heat stress. We demonstrate that the metabolic state of the coral host is a key factor in the onset of the breakdown of the symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to predict the stability of the coral holobiont in a changing environment. This may ultimately help us to design effective management and conservation strategies for coral reefs.

The intestinal epithelium is a major barrier between the host and the environment. It is also a major target of cancer, as it is the site of origin for 90% of all human cancers. Here, we show that the intestinal tumorigenesis leads to a dysregulation of the microbiome, which in turn triggers a regenerative response that stimulates tumor growth. Our work identifies a mechanism that links the tumorigenesis to the microbiome, and it provides a potential therapeutic target to control tumor growth and restore intestinal homeostasis. Our findings may also have implications for the development of cancer therapies that target the microbiome.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women worldwide. Despite advances in treatment, the majority of patients relapse, and the development of resistance to therapy is common. In this study, we show that treatment with chemotherapy enhances the expression of the orphan receptor ROR1 in breast cancer cells, which in turn enhances the capacity of these cells to survive treatment with paclitaxel, to metastasize, and to reestablish tumor growth in mice. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer.

The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation of the Southern Hemisphere is a matter of debate. Here we show that the start of this event is linked to a volcanic eruption series, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a cooling of the stratosphere. This event is unique in the past 4,000 y and may have contributed to the start of accelerated deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are a major source of animal protein for hundreds of millions of people, but they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and the sustainability of fisheries. We find that river fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that poor and undernourished populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our analysis also reveals that the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our map of riverine fisheries can be used to inform conservation and management efforts to protect both food security and species diversity. (Less)

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries are considered as a promising solution for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of the material are responsible for the high capacity and the safe operation of the batteries. This work provides a new perspective for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to be essential for regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of novel factors that regulate regeneration in the adult nervous system.

Recombination is a key process in the generation of genetic diversity and the maintenance of genomic stability. In many organisms, including humans, the pattern of recombination is known to be highly variable across the genome. Here, we describe the pattern of recombination in a wild population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions showing no detectable recombination. We also find that the pattern of recombination is highly polarized, with the highest rates of recombination occurring near the start of genes. These results suggest that the pattern of recombination in plants may be more similar to that in yeast than to that in mammals.

The brain is a dynamic system, and the study of its resting state is a fundamental issue in neuroscience. Here, we show that the resting state of the brain can be directly measured by a noninvasive technique, positron emission tomography, and that this can be used to identify and validate the main resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We also show that the resting state of the brain can be used to monitor the progression of the disease and to assess the effectiveness of treatment.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA, and its presence is a strong indicator of the stability and translation of the mRNA. We report the discovery of a second 5′ modification in yeast, a 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap. We show that NAD-capped mRNAs are produced cotranscriptionally, and that they are enriched in mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end-processed. This finding suggests that the NAD-cap could be involved in the regulation of mitochondrial translation.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. The present study shows that DNA methylation at specific loci associated with glycemia persist for several years during the EDIC Study and support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer, and there is a need for the identification of new therapeutic targets. We show that the cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is expressed in the majority of TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. We also show that FSIP1 is required for the growth of TNBC cells in vitro and in vivo and that it promotes autophagy, which in turn, sensitizes TNBC cells to chemotherapy. These findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disorder with a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in a significant proportion of alcohol-dependent subjects, and that this alteration is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of the gut barrier and in the behavioral symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. These compounds are important for the overall flavor of the fruit, but the biosynthesis of many of them is unknown. We report the identification of a gene, SlTNH1, that is essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also describe a tobacco plant transformation system that can be used to study the biosynthesis of these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of these important flavor compounds. Ultimately, this knowledge will be useful for improving the flavor of tomato fruit. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This finding is important because it suggests that the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning may be more severe than previously thought. Our results also highlight the importance of considering the thermal tolerance of species when assessing the impacts of climate change on biodiversity. This is because the thermal tolerance of species is a key determinant of the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub in the brain, connecting the hippocampus to the rest of the cortex. It is also involved in spatial navigation. However, the organization of its neurons is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that the neurons in this area are organized into different clusters, and that the neurons that are most strongly tuned to the position of the animal are also strongly tuned to the direction of its head. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of the neurons in MEC and may help us to understand how they work. This knowledge could lead to the development of new technologies for studying and treating neurological disorders.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by many different factors. One of the most important factors is the photoperiod, which is the amount of light that plants receive. Flowering can be induced by a short photoperiod, and this is the basis for the cultivation of many plants. Dodder is a parasitic plant that is able to synchronize its flowering with that of its host. We show that the flowering of the host is required for the flowering of the dodder. This study demonstrates that flowering is a complex process that is controlled by many different factors.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra. The precise nature of the pathology in this disease is not fully understood, but it is clear that it is not confined to the nigra. Here we describe a previously unrecognized system of dopamine-containing neurons that are located in the striatum and that receive input from striosomes, the part of the nucleus accumbens that is thought to be involved in the control of reward and motivation. We suggest that this system is important in the control of movement and motivation and that it is affected in Parkinson’s disease.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they “click.” But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rated the felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of felt connection. Within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. SAN cells are responsible for this function, and the normal rate of the heart is determined by the number of SAN cells and their intrinsic rhythmicity. The SAN rhythm is controlled by a complex system of electrical and Ca2+ signals. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1), a regulator of Ca2+ signals, is a key regulator of the Ca2+ clock in the SAN.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well established. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote rice resistance against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in the metabolism of ether lipids is well known, but the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in the metabolism of other lipids is less known. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism in murine macrophages. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages and for the expression of proinflammatory cytokines. Our results provide a link between ether lipid metabolism and other lipid classes and suggest that modulation of ether lipid metabolism may be a target for the treatment of inflammatory diseases.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by a number of different mechanisms. Here we propose a mechanism that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is based on the idea that information is stored in the dynamic properties of the neuron, rather than in the membrane potential itself. We show that this mechanism can support memory on a variety of timescales, and that it is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic compounds or to seek out nutrients. Thus, they are dependent on the delivery of molecules to the cell for survival. In this work, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver molecules to plants, including small interfering RNAs (siRNAs) that can silence a target gene. We show that the size, shape, and location of the siRNA attachment site on the DNA nanostructure are important for the delivery and gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of using DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters that are important for the delivery and gene silencing efficiencies. This work provides a platform for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and opens up a new avenue for the development of plant-based therapeutics.

The world’s largest lakes are often viewed as remote and distant from human activities, but this study shows that small tributaries can be a major source of nutrients to the nearshore zone of these lakes. We show that the majority of the nutrients delivered to the nearshore zone of Lake Michigan come from small tributaries, which are often overlooked in nutrient management efforts. Our findings suggest that small tributaries may be a major source of coastal eutrophication, and that nutrient management efforts should focus on these areas. This study provides a framework for understanding the role of small tributaries in coastal eutrophication and provides a model for how to assess the relative importance of different sources of nutrients to the nearshore zone of large water bodies. This approach could be applied to other large water bodies to better understand the role of small tributaries in coastal eutrophication.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environment. This finding is of interest in the context of the current debate on the origin of life, where the availability of a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations is often invoked as a possible source of the fine-tuning required for the emergence of life.

This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the effects of NMDA-receptor antibodies on the brain. It also offers a potential explanation for the variability in the clinical presentation of patients with this disease.

The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid climate change, and it is important to understand how the system responded to abrupt warming in the past. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global warming and that the warming was accompanied by an increase in atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that the warming was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and that the warming was accompanied by an increase in the extent of seafloor anoxia. These results provide insights into the potential for the current rapid climate change to have significant impacts on the Earth system.

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation, and many countries and corporations have made commitments to reduce this impact. Certification is the main tool used to fulfill these commitments, and the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most common certification scheme. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has not been well studied. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Nevertheless, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for the palm oil industry, but it is an important tool that can be used in combination with other strategies to reduce deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a key regulator of the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. However, the study of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Less)

Sex determination is a fundamental feature of animal biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major focus of research. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single gene, but in others, multiple genes are involved. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple genes on sex determination in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that multiple genes interact to produce four possible sexes in this species, and that the modular nature of these four sexes results in variation in a variety of morphological and behavioral traits. These results suggest that multiple genes can produce a variety of outcomes, and that the modular nature of these outcomes can be used to understand the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. This work provides a framework for understanding the evolutionary consequences of multiple genes involved in sex determination. (Less)

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by a variety of reactive oxygen species and reactive carbonyl species. These species can damage the retina and contribute to the development of age-related macular degeneration. We show that the level of iron in the retina can influence the levels of reactive carbonyl species and the photodegradation of the retinal pigment epithelium. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies to reduce the oxidative damage to the retina. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of specialization is one of the most important processes in ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of morphological changes that lead to specialization is not well understood. We show that the evolution of specialization in the pelagic cnidarian siphonophores is linked to the evolution of their specialized prey-capture structures. Our results provide insights into the evolution of specialization and morphological innovation, and help us understand how the structure of food webs has changed over time.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important and enigmatic aspects of human evolution. The study of the hominin hand is complicated by the fact that the fossil record is incomplete, and that the features of the hand that are most distinctive in modern humans are absent in early hominins. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a feature that is present in modern humans and Neandertals but absent in all earlier hominins. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key derived feature of the human hand.

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon pool is a key metabolic pathway that is dysregulated in cancer. Here we report the discovery of a small molecule that inhibits both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2 (SHMT1/2) in a dual-inhibitory manner. We show that this dual inhibition blocks the growth of colon cancer xenografts in mice. We also show that the one-carbon donor, formate, can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We further show that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import in DLBCL cell lines, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These results provide a rationale for the use of SHMT inhibitors in the treatment of DLBCL. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This study provides evidence that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This finding is important because it shows that, in addition to the well-known negative impacts of deforestation on the environment, there are also negative impacts on people’s health. This study also provides evidence that the impacts of deforestation on people’s diets can be mitigated by the presence of natural landscapes such as forests. This finding has important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets and health, and in meeting the goals of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.

Mechanization has been a key driver of the Green Revolution, allowing for the expansion of agricultural land and the production of more food. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
